title: Meet Australia's new million-dollar suburbs
text:
"Demand is mostly coming from first-home buyers who were priced out during the 2016-2017 boom," he said.

First-time buyers have come back into the market with a real sense of urgency. — Chris Bates, Sydney-based mortgage broker

"They're still feeling the pain from missing out in the last boom and they're frustrated that they didn't buy in 2018 when the market was down.

Redfern units are now worth more than a million dollars on average.

"After the election and with the interest rate cut, all the first-time buyers have come back into the market with a real sense of urgency."

Since June, the median unit price in Haymarket jumped 16.1 per cent to $1,138,832 while Redfern notched up a 9.5 per cent growth to $1,005,310.

Local selling agent Shannan Whitney of Bresic Whitney, who sold a penthouse in Redfern last April for a record-breaking $3.4 million, said it was not surprising to see units in the suburb cross the million-dollar median threshold.

Advertisement

"I think the strong increase in prices for units in Redfern validates the suburb's huge popularity among buyers of this particular type of property," Mr Whitney said.

"We're seeing a lot of affluent younger buyers coming in and snapping up two-bedroom units because they want to be close to work and prefer the edgy and still relatively undervalued homes in Redfern compared to Surry Hills."

HighSpec Properties buyers' agent Amanda Gould noted that Redfern had all the growth fundamentals but had not reached its true value yet.

"Properties are still relatively cheap compared to the more mature areas such as Potts Point," she said. "You can still buy beautiful terraces with outdoor areas that you wouldn't get in other locations for the same price that close to the city.

Noosaville is one of the newest members of the million-dollar club.

"There are a lot of quality warehouse apartments in the suburb and they hold their value. They're more interesting than the generic high-rise apartments."

Ms Gould said Redfern was poised to see further growth thanks to its proximity to the emerging tech hub of South Eveleigh where major companies such as the Commonwealth Bank are relocating to.

Demand for lifestyle suburbs also fuelled strong gains in NSW's Kangaroo Valley, south of Sydney, where median house prices hopped 19.2 per cent to $1,042,927 between June and September.

Advertisement

It's a similar picture in Beaumaris in Victoria where the median unit price climbed by 14.7 per cent in just three months fuelled by buyers seeking out properties in the bayside suburb.

Ainslie, the only suburb in the ACT to join the million-dollar club for the first time, racked up 10.8 per cent capital growth over the same period amid growing demand and low housing supply in the area.

Australia's newly minted million-dollar suburbs
description: Sixty-eight Australian suburbs have crossed the million-dollar median price mark since June, boosted by record low interest rates.
